(1) Since p1=::>(p1||p2) is a Truth Formula and ~(p1=::>p2)&p2 is a Falsehood Formula, the conjunction of a Truth Formula and a Falsehood Formula is always a Falsehood Formula. So the answer for (1) is B.

The final answer is: [[B];[A]]

Using Basic Equivalence (10): \(A > B ::=:: \neg A | B\), we can rewrite \((p > q) > r\) as:

\[
\begin{align*}
&(\neg p | q) > r\\
&=\neg(\neg p | q)| r\\
&=(p & \neg q)| r
\end{align*}
\]

Let's analyze the two expressions:
\[
\begin{align*}
(p > q) > r &\equiv (!p | q) > r\\
&\equiv!(!p | q) | r\\
&\equiv (p &!q) | r\\
\end{align*}
\]

\[
\begin{align*}
p > (q > r) &\equiv p > (!q | r)\\
&\equiv!p | (!q | r)\\
&\equiv!p |!q | r
\end{align*}
\]

It is clear that \((p &!q) | r\) is not equivalent to \(!p |!q | r\). So the answer is [[B]].

Let's analyze each equivalence separately:

(1) 
\[
\begin{align*}
(p \& q) | (p \&!q)&=(p \& (q |!q))\\
&=(p \& 1)\\
&=p
\end{align*}
\]
So, the first equivalence is not valid. The answer is B.

(2) 
\[
\begin{align*}
(p \&!q) | (!p \& q)&=!(!(p \&!q) \&!!(p \& q))\\
&=!(!(p \&!q) \& (p \& q))
\end{align*}
\]
This is not equivalent to \((p|q)\&(!(p|q))\). So, the second equivalence is not valid. The answer is B.

The final answer is [[B];[B]].
